2026-01-30.content:
Spanner supports the `UUID` data type for both
GoogleSQL and PostgreSQL-dialect databases. This
data type stores universally unique identifiers (UUIDs) as 128-bit values.

You can use the GoogleSQL
[`NEW_UUID()`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/utility-functions#new_uuid)
function or the PostgreSQL
[`gen_random_uuid()`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/postgresql/functions#utility) to
function to create UUID values.

For more information, see
[Use a universally unique identifier (UUID)](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/schema-design#uuid_primary_key).

summary.title: Spanner now supports UUID data type
summary.summary: Spanner now supports the UUID data type for both GoogleSQL and PostgreSQL-dialect databases. This feature allows you to store universally unique identifiers as 128-bit values, simplifying the management of unique IDs within your databases.

2026-01-28.content:
Spanner supports the following compression functions:

* [`ZSTD_COMPRESS`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/compression-functions#zstd_compress)
* [`ZSTD_DECOMPRESS_TO_BYTES`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/compression-functions#zstd_decompress_to_bytes)
* [`ZSTD_DECOMPRESS_TO_STRING`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/compression-functions#zstd_decompress_to_string)

These functions use the Zstandard (Zstd) lossless data compression algorithm to
compress and decompress `STRING` or `BYTES` values. For more information, see
[Compression functions](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/compression-functions).

summary.title: Spanner adds Zstandard compression functions
summary.summary: Spanner now supports Zstandard compression and decompression for STRING and BYTES data. These new functions, ZSTD_COMPRESS, ZSTD_DECOMPRESS_TO_BYTES, and ZSTD_DECOMPRESS_TO_STRING, allow for efficient data handling within Spanner.

2026-01-26.content:
Columnar engine for Spanner is now in [Public
Preview](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages). Columnar
engine is a storage technique used with analytical queries to speed up scans up
to 200 times faster on live operational data without affecting transaction
workloads. In databases or tables enabled with columnar engine, this release:

* Supports the ability to execute columnar queries automatically and perform
  faster columnar scans using vectorized execution.
* Provides a new [major compaction API](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/manual-data-compaction)
  to accelerate the conversion of non-columnar data into columnar data.

For more information, see the
[Columnar engine for Spanner overview](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/columnar-engine).

summary.title: Spanner Columnar Engine in Public Preview
summary.summary: Spanner's new columnar engine is now in public preview, offering significantly faster analytical query scans on live data without impacting transactional workloads. This feature enhances query performance through vectorized execution and introduces a new API for data conversion.

2026-01-20.content:
You can create Spanner [regional instance configurations](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/instance-configurations#available-configurations-regional)
in Bangkok, Thailand (`asia-southeast3`). For more information, see
[Google Cloud locations](https://cloud.google.com/about/locations) and
[Spanner pricing](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/pricing).

summary.title: Spanner instances now available in Bangkok
summary.summary: You can now create Spanner regional instance configurations in Bangkok, Thailand (asia-southeast3). This expands the global reach of Spanner, allowing for lower latency for applications in the region. Visit the Google Cloud locations and Spanner pricing pages for more details.

2026-01-13.content:
Several updates have been made to [full-text search](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/full-text-search):

* [Named schemas](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/full-text-search/search-indexes#create_and_query_a_search_index_for_a_named_schema)
  support full-text search.
* Spanner search indexes can
  [accelerate pattern matching expressions](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/full-text-search/pattern-matching-function-acceleration)
  such as `LIKE`, `STARTS_WITH`, and `ENDS_WITH` for pattern matching, and
  `REGEXP_CONTAINS` for regular expression matching.
* [`TOKENIZE_FULLTEXT`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/search_functions#tokenize_fulltext)
  has an argument for removing diacritics. `SEARCH` and `SCORE`
  use this if the data was tokenized with this option.
* [`TOKENIZE_SUBSTRING`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/full-text-search/substring-search)
  supports emojis.

summary.title: Full-text search updates
summary.summary: Full-text search in Spanner has been enhanced with named schema support, accelerated pattern matching, diacritic removal, and emoji support for substring searches.

2026-01-05.content:
You can use [SQL views](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/views) to create a graph. For
requirements, considerations, and the benefits of using SQL views to create a
graph, see
[Overview of graphs created from SQL views](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/graph/graph-with-views-overview).
To learn how to create a graph from views, see
[Create a property graph from SQL views](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/graph/graph-with-views-how-to).

summary.title: Create graphs using SQL views
summary.summary: You can now create property graphs using SQL views. This feature offers a new way to model and query your data. Learn more about the requirements, considerations, and how to create graphs from views.

2025-12-18.content:
The GoogleSQL function
[`ELEMENT_DEFINITION_NAME`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/graph-gql-functions#element_definition_name)
is available. `ELEMENT_DEFINITION_NAME` returns the name of the graph element
table underlying a graph element.

summary.title: New Graph Element Function Available
summary.summary: A new GoogleSQL function, ELEMENT_DEFINITION_NAME, is now available. This function allows you to retrieve the name of the underlying graph element table for any given graph element. This can be useful for understanding your graph data structure.

2025-12-17.content:
You can build data agents that interact with the data in your
database using conversational language. Use these data agents as tools to
empower your applications. For more information, see [Data agents overview](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/data-agent-overview). This feature is available in [Preview](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages), and access to it requires a [sign-up](https://forms.gle/pJByTWfenZAWbaXo7).

summary.title: Build conversational data agents
summary.summary: Empower your applications by building data agents that interact with your database using conversational language. This new feature, currently in preview, allows you to use these agents as tools for seamless data interaction. Sign up to gain access to this exciting new capability.

2025-12-12.content:
Spanner now supports the PostgreSQL `generate_series()` function. You can use
this function to create a sequence of numbers. For more information, see
[Set returning functions](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/postgresql/functions#set-returning-functions).

summary.title: PostgreSQL generate_series() function now supported
summary.summary: Spanner now supports the PostgreSQL generate_series() function. This function allows you to create sequences of numbers within your database queries. This feature enhances Spanner's compatibility with PostgreSQL applications.

2025-12-11.content:
Spanner [Data Boost](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/databoost/databoost-overview) now includes a
new quota, [Data Boost concurrent requests in milli-operations per second per
region](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/databoost/databoost-quotas), which applies more
fine-grained control over how multiple concurrent requests for your project
share Data boost resources. Instead of counting 1 request against 1 unit of
quota under the existing [concurrency quota regime](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/databoost/databoost-quotas),
Data Boost now splits a request at a granularity of 1/1000, allowing for a
greater number of concurrent requests to make progress. For more information,
see [Quotas and limits](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/quotas#data_boost_limits).

summary.title: Spanner Data Boost Enhances Concurrency Control
summary.summary: Spanner Data Boost has introduced a new quota for concurrent requests, measured in milli-operations per second per region. This change allows for more granular control and a greater number of concurrent requests to utilize Data Boost resources effectively.

2025-12-11.content:
Spanner Graph supports using the
[`ANY CHEAPEST`](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/graph/work-with-paths#any-cheapest) path search
prefix in a query to return the path with the lowest total compute cost. For
more information, see
[Path search prefix](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/graph-patterns#search_prefix)
in the [Graph Query Language](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/graph-intro)
reference.

summary.title: Spanner Graph: Find Cheapest Paths
summary.summary: Spanner Graph now supports the ANY CHEAPEST path search prefix. This allows you to efficiently find the path with the lowest compute cost within your graph data. It's a powerful addition for optimizing graph queries.

2025-12-10.content:
Spanner now supports the following new columns in the `SPANNER_SYS`
[oldest active queries](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/introspection/oldest-active-queries)
table:

* `CLIENT_IP_ADDRESS`
* `API_CLIENT_HEADER`
* `USER_AGENT_HEADER`
* `SERVER_REGION`
* `PRIORITY`
* `TRANSACTION_TYPE`

You can also view these columns in the Spanner **query insights** page
on the Google Cloud console. For more information, see
[Monitor active queries](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/monitor-active-queries#view-longest-running-queries).

summary.title: Spanner Adds New Columns to Oldest Active Queries
summary.summary: Spanner's `SPANNER_SYS` table now includes new columns such as client IP address, API client header, user agent, server region, priority, and transaction type for the `oldest_active_queries` view. These new details are also visible in the Spanner query insights page within the Google Cloud console, enhancing query monitoring capabilities.

2025-12-03.content:
String values in
[Spanner Studio query results](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/manage-data-using-console#create-modify-query-data)
are now enclosed in double quotes, providing a clear visual cue to differentiate
string values from other data types. This enhancement is for display purposes
only and does not affect how data is exported or accessed.

summary.title: Query results now quote strings
summary.summary: String values in query results are now enclosed in double quotes. This provides a clear visual cue to differentiate strings from other data types. This change is for display purposes only.

2025-11-20.content: Query optimizer version 8 is now the [default version](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/query-optimizer/versions) for Spanner.

summary.title: Query optimizer version 8 is now the default for Spanner.
summary.summary: Query optimizer version 8 is now the default version for Spanner. This upgrade brings performance improvements and enhanced capabilities to your database queries.

2025-11-11.content:
[Spanner Studio](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/manage-data-using-console)
now supports several new export options for your query results. You can export
to a CSV or JSON file, Google Sheets, or copy the results to a clipboard. For
more information, see
[Create, modify, and query your data](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/manage-data-using-console#create-modify-query-data).

summary.title: Spanner Studio New Export Options
summary.summary: Spanner Studio now offers versatile export options for query results, including CSV, JSON, Google Sheets, and clipboard copy.

2025-11-10.content:
Spanner now automatically provides recommendations to apply
[schema design best practices](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/schema-design)
to your databases. You can view these schema issue recommendations on the
Spanner Studio page for your database. For more information, see
[View schema design best practice recommendations](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/manage-data-using-console#recommend-schema-best).
This feature is in [Preview](https://cloud.google.com/products/#product-launch-stages%22%3E).

summary.title: New feature: Automatic schema recommendations
summary.summary: Spanner now offers automatic recommendations for schema design best practices to help you optimize your databases. View these suggestions on the Spanner Studio page.

summary.title: Client Library Updates
summary.summary: This is a monthly digest of client library updates. Key changes include bug fixes, dependency updates, and documentation improvements across Java, Node.js, and Python libraries.

2025-10-29.content: [Named schemas](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/named-schemas) are supported in Spanner Graph. For more information, see [Spanner Graph schema overview](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/graph/schema-overview).

summary.title: Named schemas in Spanner Graph
summary.summary: Spanner Graph now supports named schemas.

2025-10-21.content: [Schema object drop protection](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/schema-drop-protection) is now generally available. This feature protects schema objects such as tables, indexes, and columns from accidental deletion.

summary.title: Schema drop protection is now generally available
summary.summary: Schema drop protection is now generally available. This feature protects your schema objects from accidental deletion.

2025-10-20.content: You can now use the GoogleSQL [`ML.PREDICT` function](https://docs.cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/standard-sql/ml-functions#mlpredict) to convert your natural language query text into an embedding and perform approximate nearest neighbors (ANN) vector search.

summary.title: ML.PREDICT function for embeddings and ANN vector search
summary.summary: The new ML.PREDICT function allows you to convert natural language queries into embeddings for approximate nearest neighbors (ANN) vector search.

2025-10-02.content: You can now use repeatable read isolation (in [Preview](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages0)) to reduce latency and transaction abort rates for workloads that have many reads contending with fewer writes. For more information, see [Repeatable read isolation](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/isolation-levels#repeatable-read).

summary.title: Repeatable read isolation preview
summary.summary: Reduce latency and transaction abort rates with repeatable read isolation.

2025-10-01.content: The [Spanner CLI](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/spanner-cli) is generally available. Bundled with gcloud, you can use the Spanner command-line interface to open an interactive session or automate SQL executions from the shell or an input file.

summary.title: Spanner CLI Now Generally Available
summary.summary: The Spanner CLI is now generally available. Use it to open an interactive session or automate SQL executions from the shell or an input file.

summary.title: Client Library Updates: Go, Java, Node.js, Python
summary.summary: This monthly digest covers updates to client libraries across various languages, including new features like read lock mode and multiplexed sessions in Go, Java, and Node.js. It also includes bug fixes and dependency updates for improved stability and performance. Python has dropped support for versions 3.7 and 3.8.

2025-09-29.content: You can now create BigQuery [non-incremental materialized views over Spanner data](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/materialized-views-create#spanner) to improve query performance by periodically caching results. This feature is in [Preview](https://cloud.google.com/products/#product-launch-stages).

summary.title: BigQuery Materialized Views over Spanner Data
summary.summary: BigQuery now supports non-incremental materialized views over Spanner data, enhancing query performance through result caching. This feature is currently in Preview.

2025-09-25.content: The Cassandra interface for Spanner is now generally available. The Cassandra interface lets you take advantage of Spanner's fully managed, scalable, and highly available infrastructure using familiar Cassandra tools and syntax. For more information, see [Cassandra interface](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/non-relational/cassandra-overview), [Migrate from Cassandra to Spanner](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/non-relational/migrate-from-cassandra-to-spanner), and [Connect to Spanner using the Cassandra interface](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/non-relational/connect-cassandra-adapter).

summary.title: Cassandra interface for Spanner now available
summary.summary: The Cassandra interface for Spanner is now generally available, allowing you to leverage Spanner's robust infrastructure with familiar Cassandra tools and syntax.

2025-09-23.content: You can now use [read lease](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/read-lease) regions to reduce latency for strong reads in multi-region or dual-region instances. Read leases use designated non-leader, read-write or read-only regions to serve strong reads locally, eliminating the network round trip to the leader region that is typically required. This feature is [generally available](https://cloud.google.com/products/#product-launch-stages) (GA).

summary.title: Read leases for reduced latency
summary.summary: Reduce latency for strong reads with read leases. This feature is now generally available.

2025-09-23.content: You can now use the dedicated [Gemini CLI extension for Spanner](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/pre-built-tools-with-mcp-toolbox) to execute SQL statements and query your Spanner instance using natural language controls.

summary.title: Gemini CLI extension for Spanner
summary.summary: Query your Spanner instance using natural language.

2025-09-22.content: You can now run federated queries against [PostgreSQL dialect databases in Spanner](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/postgresql/overview) using [BigQuery external datasets](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/spanner-external-datasets) using GoogleSQL; this includes [cross-region federated queries](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/spanner-federated-queries#cross_region_queries). This feature is [generally available](https://cloud.google.com/products/#product-launch-stages) (GA).

summary.title: Spanner PostgreSQL dialect databases now available for BigQuery external datasets
summary.summary: You can now run federated queries against PostgreSQL dialect databases in Spanner using BigQuery external datasets. This feature is now generally available and supports cross-region queries.

2025-09-17.content: Spanner Graph support of schemaless schemas is [generally available](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages) (GA). For more information, see [Manage schemaless data with Spanner Graph](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/graph/manage-schemaless-data).

summary.title: Spanner Graph Schemaless Support is Now GA
summary.summary: Spanner Graph now supports schemaless schemas, which is now generally available. This feature allows for more flexible data management.

2025-09-03.content:
You can import your own data into a Spanner database by using a CSV file, a MySQL dump file, or a PostgreSQL dump file.

Additionally, you can populate new databases in an existing Spanner instance from sample datasets that
help you explore Spanner capabilities such as its relational model, full-text search, vector search, or Spanner Graph.

For more information, see [Create and manage databases](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/create-manage-databases).

summary.title: Import data into Spanner
summary.summary: Easily import data into Spanner using CSV or dump files, or explore capabilities with sample datasets.

summary.title: Client Library Updates Digest
summary.summary: This digest covers recent updates to client libraries, including new features, bug fixes, and documentation improvements for Spanner in Go, Java, Node.js, and Python.

2025-08-25.content:
You can now terminate multiple active queries in your Spanner instance. Active queries are long-running queries that might affect the performance of your instance. Monitoring these queries can help you identify causes of instance latency and high CPU usage. Terminating queries might help free up resources and reduce the load on your instance.

For more information, see [Monitor active queries](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/monitor-active-queries#terminate-query).

summary.title: Terminate Multiple Queries
summary.summary: You can now terminate multiple active queries in your Spanner instance to improve performance.

2025-09-15.content: The Cassandra interface for Spanner is now generally available. The Cassandra interface lets you take advantage of Spanner's fully managed, scalable, and highly available infrastructure using familiar Cassandra tools and syntax. For more information, see [Cassandra interface](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/non-relational/cassandra-overview), [Migrate from Cassandra to Spanner](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/non-relational/migrate-from-cassandra-to-spanner), and [Connect to Spanner using the Cassandra interface](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/non-relational/connect-cassandra-adapter).

summary.title: Cassandra interface for Spanner now available
summary.summary: The Cassandra interface for Spanner is now generally available. This feature allows you to leverage Spanner's robust infrastructure with familiar Cassandra tools and syntax.

2025-08-14.content: You can now use [cross region federated queries](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/spanner-federated-queries#cross_region_queries) to query Spanner tables from regions other than the source BigQuery region. These cross region queries incur additional [Spanner network egress charges](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/pricing#network). This feature is [generally available](https://cloud.google.com/products/#product-launch-stages) (GA).

summary.title: Cross-Region Queries for Spanner
summary.summary: Query Spanner data across regions.

2025-08-13.content:
Spanner offers a predefined library of over [80 MySQL functions](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/reference/mysql/user_defined_functions_all) that you can install in a database. These functions let you perform operations that are common in the MySQL environments directly with Spanner. They can help reduce the changes required when migrating workloads from MySQL to Spanner.

These functions are packaged as user-defined functions that can be installed from an open-source DDL script hosted on GitHub. For more information, see [Install MySQL functions in Spanner](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/install-mysql-functions).

summary.title: New MySQL functions in Spanner
summary.summary: Spanner now supports over 80 MySQL functions to simplify migration and operations.

2025-08-05.content: Columnar engine for Spanner is now in Preview. Columnar engine is a storage technique used with analytics queries to speed up scans. Spanner columnar engine accelerates analytical query performance on live operational data by up to 200 times without affecting transaction workloads. This eliminates the need for ETL into separate data warehouses while maintaining strong consistency. For more information, see the [Columnar engine for Spanner overview](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/columnar-engine).

summary.title: Spanner Adds New Feature
summary.summary: Spanner columnar engine speeds up analytics on live data.

2025-08-01.content:
When you create the free trial instance using the Google Cloud console, Spanner creates and preloads it with a sample database for an ecommerce store. You can use the free trial instance to explore the dataset and learn about Spanner capabilities with pre-loaded queries.

For more information, see [Spanner free trial instances](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/free-trial-instance).

summary.title: Spanner Free Trial Instance
summary.summary: Explore Spanner with a free trial instance, preloaded with an e-commerce sample database and queries.

2025-07-31.content: You can use [continuous queries](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/continuous-queries-introduction) to [export BigQuery data into Spanner in real time](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/export-to-spanner). This feature is in [preview](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages).

summary.title: Real-time BigQuery to Spanner Export
summary.summary: Real-time data export to Spanner.

summary.title: Client Library Updates
summary.summary: Client library updates for Java and Python Spanner.

2025-07-14.content: [Spanner Data Boost](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/databoost/databoost-overview) supports data stored on hard disk drives (HDD). This feature is [generally available](https://cloud.google.com/products/#product-launch-stages) (GA).

summary.title: Spanner Data Boost supports HDDs
summary.summary: Spanner Data Boost, now generally available, supports data stored on hard disk drives (HDD).

2025-07-01.content: The performance of the `ANY` and the [`ANY SHORTEST`](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/graph/work-with-paths#any-shortest) algorithms have been improved. These algorithms are used to find Spanner Graph paths. For more information, see [`ANY` and `ANY SHORTEST` paths](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/graph/queries-overview#any-and-any-shortest-paths).

summary.title: Performance improvements for ANY and ANY SHORTEST algorithms
summary.summary: The performance of the ANY and ANY SHORTEST algorithms, used for finding Spanner Graph paths, has been improved.

2025-06-30.content:
Spanner supports the following new client-side metrics to the Spanner API frontend (AFE) and Google frontend (GFE) for Java and Go applications:

* AFE connectivity error count
* AFE latencies
* GFE connectivity error count
* GFE latencies

These metrics can be used with server-side metrics to enable faster troubleshooting of performance and latency issues. For more information, see
[Client-side metrics descriptions](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/client-side-metrics-descriptions).

summary.title: New Client-Side Metrics for Spanner
summary.summary: New client-side metrics for Java and Go applications are now available for the Spanner API, providing AFE and GFE connectivity error counts and latencies. These metrics, when used with server-side data, can help in diagnosing performance and latency issues more effectively.

2025-06-30.content: To troubleshoot or understand your Spanner queries better, you can download and save your [query execution plan](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/query-execution-plans) as a JSON file. You can now use the content of this file to see a visualization of the query execution plan in Spanner Studio. For more information, see [Take a tour of the query plan visualizer](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/tune-query-with-visualizer#visual-plan-tour).

summary.title: Spanner Query Execution Plan Visualization
summary.summary: You can now visualize your Spanner query execution plan with a JSON file download, making it easier to troubleshoot and understand your queries.

summary.title: Client Library Updates Digest: Library Updates Digest
summary.summary: This digest covers updates to client libraries, including new features like support for TOKENIZE_JSON and EXISTS in Go, and improvements to directpath and metrics in Java. It also includes various bug fixes and dependency updates.

2025-06-24.content: You can directly connect and interact with your Spanner database using the Spanner CLI, an interactive shell for Spanner that is built into the Google Cloud CLI. You can use the Spanner CLI to start an interactive session and automate SQL executions from the shell or an input file. This feature is available in [Preview](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages). For more information, see [Spanner CLI quickstart](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/spanner-cli).

summary.title: Spanner CLI available in preview
summary.summary: Interact with your Spanner database using the Spanner CLI, a new feature built into the Google Cloud CLI. You can use this tool to start interactive sessions and automate SQL executions.

2025-06-20.content: A new free trial creation work flow makes it easier to start your Spanner free trial. With a free trial instance, you can learn and explore Spanner for 90 days at no cost. You can create relational (GoogleSQL and PostgreSQL) databases and deploy NoSQL models (Spanner Graph, Vector search, and Full-text search) in a single, fully managed database. For more information, see [Spanner free trial instances overview](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/free-trial-instance).

summary.title: New Spanner Free Trial Workflow
summary.summary: Easily start your Spanner free trial with our new workflow. Explore Spanner for 90 days at no cost, supporting both relational and NoSQL models in a single, managed database.

2025-06-11.content: Column operations statistics are [generally available](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages). They help you get insights into and monitor the usage of columns in your database. For more information, see [Column operations statistics](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/docs/introspection/column-operations-statistics).

summary.title: Column Operations Statistics Now Available
summary.summary: Get insights into and monitor your database column usage with the new column operations statistics feature.

2025-06-02.content: BigQuery now supports using [Spanner external datasets](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/spanner-external-datasets) with [authorized views](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/authorized-views), [authorized routines](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/authorized-routines), and [Cloud resource connections](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/create-cloud-resource-connection). This feature is [generally available](https://cloud.google.com/products?e=48754805&hl=en#product-launch-stages) (GA).

summary.title: BigQuery adds Spanner external datasets support
summary.summary: BigQuery now supports Spanner external datasets with authorized views, authorized routines, and Cloud resource connections. This feature is generally available.

summary.title: Client Library Updates: Go, Java, Node.js, and Python
summary.summary: This digest covers recent updates to client libraries, including new features for Spanner in Go and Java, such as support for DROP/ALTER SEARCH INDEX and AFE/gRPC metrics. Node.js has seen breaking changes with migration to Node 18 and removal of the arrify package, while Python library updates include interval type support and multiplexed sessions.

2025-05-27.content: Spanner now supports [cross regional federated queries](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/spanner-federated-queries#cross_region_queries) from BigQuery, which allows BigQuery users to query Spanner tables from regions other than their BigQuery region. Users will not incur any Spanner [network egress charges](https://cloud.google.com/spanner/pricing#network) during the preview period. This feature is in [Preview](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages).

summary.title: Cross-region queries for Spanner
summary.summary: BigQuery users can now query Spanner tables in different regions. No Spanner network egress charges apply during the preview period.
